results.headline: Journey Across a Wide Spectrum

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The United States of Autism

results.summary_short: “The United States of Autism” follows Richard Everts, the director, whose son is autistic, as he journeys across the country to visit families affected by autism.

results.headline: The Vladimir and Estragon of Roadwork

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Prince Avalanche

results.summary_short: In David Gordon Green’s offbeat film “Prince Avalanche,” two young men — one pompous, one slow on the uptake — take a job painting lines on a stretch of highway.

results.headline: Lives Defined Daily by Prescription Drugs

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Off Label

results.summary_short: Michael Palmieri and Donal Mosher’s film focuses on Americans whose lives revolve around prescription drugs.

results.headline: A Woman Who Showed It All Yet Hid Everything

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lovelace

results.summary_short: “Lovelace,” starring Amanda Seyfried as Linda Lovelace, looks at the woman who starred in the film “Deep Throat.”

results.headline: A Hole in the Ground, Worshiped and Feared

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jug Face

results.summary_short: In “Jug Face,” a pregnant teenager tries to flee a backwoods community when she learns that she may be sacrificed to a mysterious pit.

results.headline: Mismatch in Every Possible Way

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Give it a Year

results.summary_short: In the comedy “I Give It a Year,” Rose Byrne and Rafe Spall are newlyweds whose family and friends are convinced that they won’t last.

results.headline: The Worst Is Yet to Come

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Elysium

results.summary_short: “Elysium,” the second feature from the director Neill Blomkamp, stars Matt Damon as a former thief living on a ruined Earth in 2154.

results.headline: For a Crop-Duster, There’s More to Life Than Spraying the Fields

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Planes

results.summary_short: “Disney’s Planes,” an animated feature, is the story of a small plane who’s afraid of heights.

results.headline: Taking the Fast Train to Win a Mob Princess

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chennai Express

results.summary_short: The Bollywood superstar Shah Rukh Khan plays a man kidnapped by hoods and taken to an Indian village in “Chennai Express.”

results.headline: Two Brothers, Fighting Crime With Crime

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blood

results.summary_short: Two fraternal detectives wrestle with murder and morality in Nick Murphy’s crime drama “Blood.”

results.headline: Roller Coaster Emotions in Battle Over Amusement Park
results.display_title: Zipper: Coney Island's Last Wild Ride

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zipper: Coney Island's Last Wild Ride

results.summary_short: Amy Nicholson’s “Zipper” recounts the contraction and conversion of Coney Island through various voices.

results.headline: Sometimes, They’re Sort of Who They Say They Are

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We're the Millers

results.summary_short: Four people pretending to be a family smuggle marijuana from Mexico to Colorado in “We’re the Millers.”

results.headline: What a Hero Goes Through to Become a Healer

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Percy Jackson: Sea of Monsters

results.summary_short: In “Percy Jackson: Sea of Monsters,” the Golden Fleece must be retrieved to save Camp Half-Blood.

results.headline: A Challenge in the Woods

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kid-Thing

results.summary_short: In “Kid-Thing,” a young girl with little social skill faces a situation that tests her judgment.

results.headline: Moroccan Myth, Set to Music
results.display_title: Jajouka, Something Good Comes to You

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jajouka, Something Good Comes to You

results.summary_short: “Jajouka, Something Good Comes to You,” playing at the Museum of Modern Art, tells the story of a band from a Moroccan village.

results.headline: A Household Grows, and Life Becomes Unbearable

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Our Children

results.summary_short: As the size of a family grows in Joachim Lafosse’s film “Our Children,” stress rises to a dangerous level.

results.headline: Noble Spacemen, Sacrificing All for Science

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Europa Report

results.summary_short: “Europa Report” imagines a space voyage to the moons of Jupiter that goes drastically awry.

results.headline: The Cellphone Gets Its Close-Up

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Canyons

results.summary_short: “The Canyons,” Paul Schrader’s new film, written by Bret Easton Ellis and starring Lindsay Lohan, is a dispiriting work that addresses the dirty business of making movies.

results.headline: An Aging Sculptor and, Yes, His Nymph-Muse

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Artist and the Model

results.summary_short: “The Artist and the Model” centers on an elderly sculptor who finds the inspiration to work on a final masterpiece when a young Spanish woman enters the household.

results.headline: Cycling Their Way to Redemption

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rising From Ashes

results.summary_short: Narrated by Forest Whitaker, the documentary “Rising From Ashes” focuses on Rwanda’s fledgling national cycling team and its American coach.
